title: 113_s643
content: The Act titled "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" aims to enhance cost savings. The Act "Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013" is amended to require the Inspector General of an agency to refer any potential surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority identified by an employee to the Chief Financial Officer of the agency. The Chief Financial Officer of an agency can transfer surplus funds or unnecessary budget authority to the Treasury for deficit reduction, as per the Bonuses for Cost-Cutters Act of 2013. The head of an agency can retain up to 10% of transferred funds for cash awards to employees who identify surplus funds. Agencies must report on fraud disclosures, savings achieved, and cash awards given. The Director of the Office of Personnel Management ensures agency cash award programs comply with regulations and submits an annual report to Congress and the Government Accountability Office on federal cost savings and awards. The head of each agency must include cash award information in budget requests to the Office of Management and Budget. The Comptroller General of the United States submits a report to Congress every 3 years on the operation of the cost savings and awards program, with recommendations for legislative changes. Section 4509 of title 5, United States Code, prohibits certain officers from receiving cash awards under this subchapter. Section 4509 of title 5, United States Code, prohibits certain high-ranking officers from receiving cash awards under this subchapter. Prohibition of cash award to certain high-ranking officers under title 5, United States Code.
